Award.AwardTitle: Investigating effects of aqueous speciation in 13C-18O clumping and its implications for paleothermometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The recently established "clumped isotope" paleothermometer is based on the Carbon 13 - Oxygen 18 bond abundance in carbonate minerals. Although this technique is becoming more widely used, there are still many questions about the underlying processes that control geochemical signatures in bio-minerals and non-biologically formed minerals. This project will address several of these outstanding questions. Investigators will compare results from theoretical calculations and experiments to observations, including from slowly-grown naturally occurring samples such as the Devils Hole speleothem and deep-sea corals of variable mineralogy. This work should improve the ability to employ clumped isotopes in surface and subsurface systems, and identify the limitations of this technique.

This work will be highlighted in UCLA's annual Physical Sciences Outreach Day that brings 2000-3000 members of the public to the campus and a few hundred people to the exhibits. All of the participants in this project will also conduct a mineral precipitation activity with school children as part of a regular outreach program the PI runs. Support of this project will benefit an early career PI who is establishing a NSF-supported state-of-the-art isotope lab and is committed to recruiting, mentoring, and supporting outstanding early career scientists from diverse backgrounds, thus furthering NSF's goals to support underrepresented groups in the Earth Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to advance our ability to use a new tool that is being applied by companies for natural resource extraction, and by scientists for energy-related studies and climate change as well as a host of other types of studies such as the determination of the body temperature of dinosaurs and the history of meteorites from Mars. This tool is based on the occurrence of pairs of heavy isotopes in minerals, which we know can tell us about the thermal history of a mineral. Until our work, we did not know whether factors other than temperature can affect this isotope pairing. We conducted experiments and used computer models to determine what the effects of temperature, water chemistry, and other variables are on isotope pairing in minerals. Our work allowed us to determine the conditions in which this tool can be used with confidence, and under what circumstances factors other than temperature need to be taken into account. We applied our knowledge to study the processes associated with mineral formation in a range of samples.

For this research project, we trained students and other early-career scientists so they developed the skills needed in the workforce. We also focused on training people from a range of backgrounds that reflects the diversity of American society. As part of the work, we talked to families and school children about scientific principles.
